ReviewList.Text: There are many Einstein biographies out there, and I've read a number of them. In my opinion, this is one of the most concise and readable ones. The writing is clear and engaging, thus making the book difficult to put down. Einstein's theories are clearly explained for anyone to understand, amidst the main highlights of his life and times. I recommend this book to a wide audience, from science buffs to Einstein fans to anyone wanting to understand what is was that made Einstein so famous, and why.

The author shares personal details (as well as scientific triumphs and failures) of Einstein in such a way that you will feel like you had been Einstein's close personal friend throughout his life.  Extrememely well-written, and easy to understand. I don't have much time to read as I am a busy mom, but this book was worth making the time for.

The professor, Michio Kaku, has easily become one of my favorite authors. That Einstein was the greatest scientist of the past century there's no doubt. And the author in addition to being a physicist is able to explain, in a warm, and caring way, how Einstein pictured, in his mind, what eventually became his theory of special relativity. But there's more; Prof. Kaku provides us a glimpse of the life, thoughts, frustrations, and accomplishments of Einstein the man as well. An easy, and interesting read for sure.

ReviewList.Text: Einstein's Cosmos is a very readable book about theoretical physics topics such as relativity, quantum theory and unified field theory.  I have read books by Hawking, Carroll, Greene, Haisch and others discussing these topics and, although fascinating, these authors left me somewhat confused.  Michio Kaku presents these topics in a very understandable manner and ties them to the incredibly brilliant life of Albert Einstein.  I highly recommend this book for the layman interested in penetrating the complicated world of theoretical physics.

This book so riveting that I finished reading it one sitting. I would not share with you where I was sitting. I can only say that I created some inconvenience for rest of my family. I recommend this book to anyone who is interested in science but not found someone to explain some of the principles in simple terms without resorting to scientific jargons.  It is like a history book for evolution of quantum and relativistic theories.  It is astonishing to see such a convolution of great minds occurred in early 19th century.  Had it not been for Lorenz, Dirac, Max Born, Riemann, Minkowski the relativity theory would have come at least 50yrs later.  This book give a chronolgy of Einstein's revelation of the mind of God from the language of abstract math.
I couldn't put it down.  A very well written and interesting book about the life of Albert Einstein and his ideas.

For a person who has never read anything about physics it is very understandable and visual in nature just like Albert himself. Michio Kaku is an excellent writer who flows from one thought to the next without confusing his audience.

Excellent book. Recommend to anyone interested in learning about Einstein's theories and life. Kaku mixes the biographical info very nicely with the technical material which gives the book a nice flow. Well written and informative.An easy read. I have very little science background and was able to understand most of the material.

Michio Kaku is an excellent writer and this book is no exception.  He explains concept of physics so well that I can keep on reading without going blank.  I also enjoyed learning about Einstein's personal life along with the theoretical concepts he was developing.
Very interesting book. My grandson and I watch Michio Kaku on the science channel and this was great to get more in depth on his works.

There have been innumerable books written about Einstein and his relativity theories.  But Michio Kaku has made an interesting and useful addition to the mountain of material. The author offers the enjoyable experience of presenting Einstein's revolutionary concepts as the visual images Einstein actually contemplated when he saw the need to redefine the laws of physics and reality. Kaku does this in a clear and understandable way that gave me a much deeper appreciation of relativity. If you would like to review the well known story of Einstein's life with the addition of a picturesque explication of his strokes of genius you will find this book very satisfying.

I have had physics in high school and undergraduate school but it was introductory and non calculus based.  Michio Kaku does an amazing job explaining the history of physics, Einstein's personality and work, the changes in physics since his critical innovations, and how history itself affected Einstein and the other pioneers of this field.  Kaku, like Einstein, is able to take complex ideas and explain them in a way that is incredibly simple.  I found this book to be thoroughly engaging and I read it surprisingly fast.  I highly recommend this book.

Quantum theory is a mathematical theory, that is to say that QT only describes the structural meta-data: "data about the containers of data" --Michio Kaku's book ("Einstein's Cosmos: How Albert Einstein's Vision Transformed Our Understanding of Space and Time") shows, perhaps for the first time, Einstein's vision, the reason why Einstein believe that to be complete QM must open the containers of data with three dimensional images and stories (moving images), and transform QT from a mathematical theory into a physical theory.

As always, Michio Kaku is entertaining and understandable.  He presents Einstein, the deep thinker, the quick wit, and the very real human being, and the basics of Special and General Relativity and the incredible consequences of the eloquent E = MC2.  It reads like a mystery story, from the begining of the Big Bang to the possible end of the universe.  I'm reading it for the second time and jotting notes in the margins and underlinig key words.  Haven't done that since college.

I do not normally enjoy biographies, but this book filled a lot of blanks I had about Einstein.  An example of those questions is why Einstein did not have a direct role in the development of the atomic bomb.  At the same time it was a historic tour through scientific advances in physics beginning with special relativity and continuing through M theory.  The scientific level is good for a nonscientist such as me.

A wonderful expose of Einstein's life and his contributions. Well written and thoroughly entertaining. Every serious student of relativity and the history of science should have a copy. Thank you, Dr. Kaku, for bringing this fascinating story to the masses, in such an enjoyable manner! Includes a substantial bibliography. Gets five stars from me, if only because I detected zero mechanical or logical errors!
Accessible to everyone, I've found that this book assumes no prior education in physics but does not insult the readers intelligence.
Michio, as usual, takes a complex subject and makes it understandable!  He provides new ways of visualizing Einstien.  Not an easy thing to do!

I have been doing much research in the area of general and special relativity lately, so, much of what this book contained has been what I would call "review". This does not change the fact that Michio has a way of looking at every detail of Einstein's life from a slightly different angle, and presenting that angle in a way that gives the reader new insight into the conciousness of a genius.  There were multiple time's while reading this book that I found myself setting the book down and staring at a wall (at one particular time for more than an hour) contemplating the ramifications of the theories contained within.  After reading this book many of my questions have been answered, although I must say, an even longer list of questions are now floating around my mind due to my increased knowledge and understanding of relativity. My goal in life at this point is to sit down with Michio Kaku and ask him some of these questions, as his ability to envision and interpret the universe are unmatched by any mortal soul to date.
